markdownRemark.html:
Sometime this month last year, I quit drinking alcohol. I had no goal, no reason and no expectations. I just wanted to see what it was like. The changes that happened since not drinking are subtle, but they are very real.


First, I have been going out less at night. I barely visit bars, pubs, clubs and concerts. Traveling played a part in this as well, especially for the concerts. Activities and events at night have ended earlier – I’m usually in bed before midnight, also on weekends.

That caused me to have a much more balanced sleeping pattern. I sleep 8 hours most nights, and usually get up before 8.

I used to get up late-ish (9-10am), feel tired during the day and feel unfinished at night. I’d work late to finish stuff, leaving no time for other activities.

I barely work (professionally) in the evening anymore, except hobby projects. Instead, I spend a lot of time cooking, go on walks or play a boardgame.

Overall I feel so much more balanced. I’m relaxed, sleep well, eat well and have time to pursue things outside of work.

Now there’s one aspect that I could consider a downside of not drinking, and that’s making friends.

Drinking bonds.

I have made less friends the past year and I feel like it is harder to relate to people, or for people to relate with me.

If most people are drinking and you’re not, sometimes people, or you, feel awkward. There can be judgement from either side, which makes it harder to bond.

That has also been a reason for me to avoid some situations, activities and events.

At the same time, the friendships I did make feel stronger and deeper. I’ve had meaningful conversations instead of a shared night of fun. I’ve learnt from those people by talking about topics that interest me.

I don’t think one excludes the other. You can probably drink and have meaningful conversations. Probably in the opposite order though :-)

I have experienced this time without alcohol largely positive and have no intention to drink any time soon.

I try to not let my own preferences and decisions, on this topic and on other topics, influence my opinion on others.

I think relationships come from understanding. Sharing the same values likely means you understand each other, but you can still understand each other without sharing the same values. It just takes a bit more effort and a bit less judgement.
